summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Robert W. Sweet, requesting a limited order to unseal civil discovery materials held by the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP. The materials are sought via a grand jury subpoena for an ongoing criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking and enticement of minors. The government argues that the protective order in the civil case should be modified to allow compliance with the subpoena, citing legal precedent and the gravity of the investigation.

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: The judge presiding over the request to unseal civil discovery materials related to the Epstein investigation. The letter is addressed to him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the ongoing grand jury investigation for possible violations of sex trafficking and enticement of minors laws.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: A defendant in the referenced civil litigation (Giuffre v. Maxwell). The protective order in that case covers information implicating her privacy interests.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman

connections.description: Both are implicated in the ongoing criminal investigation and are parties to the related civil litigation, suggesting an alleged association in the underlying conduct.
The law firm is counsel for the plaintiffs in the civil litigation against Ghislaine Maxwell, placing them in an adversarial legal relationship.

events.title: Issuance of Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: The government served a grand jury subpoena on Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP for discovery materials from the civil litigation Giuffre v. Maxwell.

events.title: Government's Sealed Application
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed a sealed application under the All Writs Act, requesting a court order to modify a protective order and allow the law firm to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Ongoing Criminal Investigation
events.description: An active grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for possible violations of federal laws regarding sex trafficking of minors (18 U.S.C. §§ 1591, 1594(c)) and enticement of minors (18 U.S.C. § 2422(b)).

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office was conducting an active, non-public grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking and enticement of minors as of February 2019.
The government sought discovery materials from the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell (15 Civ. 7433) via a subpoena to the plaintiffs' law firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP.
A protective order in the civil case was the only obstacle to compliance, as the law firm was willing to comply with the subpoena.

The government argued that avoiding embarrassment is not a valid reason to uphold confidentiality against a legitimate law enforcement need, especially for grave crimes like the sexual exploitation of minors.
The investigation's existence and scope were not publicly known at the time, and the government was concerned about alerting potential targets.
